citation.article-title: Corynebacterium pyruviciproducens sp. nov., a pyruvic acid producer
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Corynebacterium pyruviciproducens sp. nov.
Corynebacterium pyruviciproducens (py.ru.vi′ci.pro.du′cens. N.L. n. acidum pyruvicum pyruvic acid; L. part. adj. producens producing; N.L. part. adj. pyruviciproducens pyruvic acid-producing).
Can grow aerobically or facultatively anaerobically at 37 and 42 °C.
Optimum growth at 37 °C under aerobic conditions.
Colonies are small (0.3–0.5 mm in diameter), circular, entire, convex and translucent after 2 days of incubation on blood agar.
Cannot reduce nitrates and CAMP test is negative.
Acid is produced from d-ribose, d-xylose, d-glucose, maltose and sucrose, but not from fructose, d-mannitol, lactose (bovine origin) or glycogen.

Cells produce esterase (C4), esterase lipase (C8), leucine arylamidase, pyrazinamidase, a small amount of naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase and pyrrolidonyl arylamidase, but no acid phosphatase, β-galactosidase, α-glucosidase, N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, lipase (C14), valine arylamidase, cystine arylamidase, α-chymotrypsin, α-galactosidase, α-fucosidase, alkaline phosphatase, α-mannosidase or β-glucosidase.
Trypsin and gelatin are not hydrolysed. β-Lactamase-negative.
Susceptible to the vibriostatic agent O/129 and highly sensitive to ampicillin, ceftriaxone, clindamycin and erythromycin.
The major cellular fatty acids are C18 : 1ω9c, C16 : 0 and summed feature 8 (C17 : 1ω8c and/or C17 : 2); no TBSA is produced.
Major MEs from glucose are acetic acid and pyruvic acid.
The type strain is 06-1773OT (=WAL 19168T =CCUG 57046T =ATCC BAA-1742T), isolated from a groin abscess specimen taken at Olive View-UCLA Medical Center in 2006.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 62 mol%.
